body: Do not forget: current region parameterization inference codes does not consider supertrait inheritance.
Can you be a little more concrete about use cases and current failure modes? I'm having a hard time picturing the implications of this.
Doesn't look like 0.6
Nominating for milestone 3, feature-complete
punting to later triage mtg with niko present.
Related to #5781
accepted for feature-complete milestone
As part of the code for #4846 I implemented a general variance inference algorithm, but I do not yet apply it to type parameters.
nominating for discussion during triage when @nikomatsakis is present

Marking as E-mentor -- this is almost entirely done. The variance inference is written. The declarations are written (in the form of marker types). The only thing missing is to update the type inferencer to consider the results of variance inference rather than treating all type parameters as invariant, and to update the vtable matching code in a similar way. Not exactly _easy_ changes but not  terribly hard with some pointers.

Assigning P-backcompat-lang, 1.0 blocker.  (The current default of invariant is backwards compatible, but niko says there's some other interaction with trait-matching that niko says makes this more important to the point of being P-backcompat-lang.)
cc me

I had a fix, which succeeded in compiling the following test from @eddyb:

``` rust
fn shorthen<'a, 'b>(x: &'b Option<&'a int>) -> Option<&'b int> {*x}
```

Basically, it substitutes type parameters with respect to the given variance as is with one twist. It treats `Bivariant` as if it were `Invariant`. Does it make sense theoretically?

@edwardw  I'm not sure it makes sense theoretically - why do you do it? I was looking at this and found a problem with bivariance too - I didn't get as far as debugging it, but I suspect treating it as invariance is just hacking around a deeper problem.

How much of this bug does your patch queue resolve? I also have patches which I think overlap with yours :-( Note for both of us: it is really useful to leave a note on an issue when you start hacking on stuff that might affect it. I think you are a fair but further along than I got, so just let me know if there is anything you don't intend to address.

@nick29581 Sure. The problem with `bivariance` is that if treating it as-is in type parameter substitution, rustc won't be able to compile `std`, `kinds.rs` in particular. It complains about unconstrained type in `Clone` and `Eq` implementations for `CovariantType` and friends.

I would say my patch is pretty close to solve this bug :)
It is most definitely bogus to treat bivariant as invariant, as discussed on IRC.

Yes, it is hacky at best. So how to bootstrapping the compilation of `kinds.rs`? It does have unconstrained types:

``` rust
#[lang="covariant_type"]
#[deriving(Eq,Clone)]
pub struct CovariantType<T>;
```

With type parameter substitution on, rustc simply couldn't pass compiling this. What are our options here?

@edwardw I guess I don't know what problem you're encountering precisely. I know you sent me some gists but I never head time to read into them. Perhaps you can repost them here. It's hard to say what the options are without knowing what the problem is, it seems to me it's likely just a bug somewhere.

@nikomatsakis, I'd like to draw your attention to this line of the PR: [combine.rs](https://github.com/mozilla/rust/pull/12828/files#diff-7465eb6da5e5362429030067a0f31234R112). Without it, the patched rustc won't be able to compile `kinds.rs`. The specific error messages are:

``` rust
#[lang="covariant_type"]
#[deriving(Eq,Clone)]  // error: cannot determine a type for this expression: unconstrained type
pub struct CovariantType<T>;
```

Same error if manually implementing the `Eq` and `Clone` traits.

@nikomatsakis @nick29581 I think I figured out what are those mysterious bivariant. They come from nullary generic type. With that handled we are one step closer to fix this bug.

Since this is going to be a change with potentially big impact, do you have some specific tests in mind for it? Or some formerly ignored tests should be turned on as part of the fix?
All is worked out. #12828 has all the details and I think it fixes both this bug and #5781 :) Please review.
Nominating for removal from 1.0 milestone because the remaining soundness issue is covered by #5781 which is already milestoned.
P-high, not 1.0.
This issue has been moved to the RFCs repo: rust-lang/rfcs#281
